childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1988-2000

You were born the year Prozac hit the market and The Simpsons premiered—two things that would define your generation's coping mechanisms for the next three decades. George H.W. Bush won the presidency that November. The Berlin Wall fell when you were barely walking. The Soviet Union collapsed before you started kindergarten.

Your childhood coincided with the tail end of analog everything. You probably had a landline with a cord that stretched across the kitchen. Saturday morning cartoons were appointment television. If you wanted to reach a friend, you called their house and talked to their mom first. The internet existed, but it made that dial-up screech and kicked everyone off the phone line.

You were six when Princess Diana died, ten when Columbine happened, thirteen during 9/11. These weren't abstract historical events—they were the background radiation of your formative years. You grew up watching the news get progressively darker while adults insisted everything was fine.

Technology-wise, you caught the transition. You probably had a CD player, then a Discman, then an iPod. Your family's first computer had a CRT monitor the size of a microwave. You learned to type on a keyboard, not a touchscreen. MySpace was your first social network, and you were probably embarrassed by your profile within six months of making it.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996. That's Pew Research's definition, which became the standard after years of people arguing about who counts. Your generation is roughly 72 million people in the US, which made you the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. You were thirteen. Old enough to understand what was happening, young enough for it to fundamentally shape your worldview. The pre-9/11 world feels like a different country. Post-9/11, everything was security theater and fear.

Your generation graduated into the 2008 financial crisis, watched housing prices triple while wages stayed flat, and somehow got blamed for killing everything from chain restaurants to the concept of home ownership. You didn't invent avocado toast—you invented the phrase 'I can't afford a house' as a personality trait.

Millennials are sandwiched between Gen X (who got theirs before the economy collapsed) and Gen Z (who never expected to get anything in the first place). You're optimistic enough to believe things could get better, cynical enough to know they probably won't.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Rain Man won Best Picture and Die Hard invented the modern action movie. Bruce Willis in a white tank top became a template Hollywood would photocopy for decades. Tom Hanks played a kid trapped in an adult's body in Big, which was basically your entire adolescence.

Musically, 1988 was peak late-'80s excess. George Michael's 'Faith' dominated. Whitney Houston was breaking records. Guns N' Roses gave us 'Sweet Child O' Mine,' which every guy at your high school tried to play on acoustic guitar. Bobby McFerrin told everyone not to worry, be happy. Nobody listened.

TV in 1988 launched shows that would define the next decade. The Simpsons premiered as a short on The Tracey Ullman Show. Roseanne brought working-class realness to primetime. The Wonder Years started making everyone nostalgic for childhoods they hadn't finished living yet.

Your childhood was peak Nickelodeon and early Cartoon Network. Your middle school years belonged to TRL, boy bands, and Britney Spears. By high school, emo music and MySpace profiles were the aesthetic. You probably had a dramatic away message and thought it was profound.

The pop culture you grew up with was pre-streaming, pre-algorithm. You couldn't skip the commercials. You couldn't binge a season in one weekend. Delayed gratification wasn't a virtue—it was just how things worked.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the Morris worm crashed 10% of the internet, which at the time was only 60,000 computers. The internet in 1988 was a government research project. Tim Berners-Lee was still sketching out what would become the World Wide Web.

Microsoft Office launched in 1988, which means every terrible PowerPoint presentation you've ever sat through has existed your entire life. Steve Jobs unveiled the NeXT computer—a $6,500 black cube that nobody bought but that influenced everything Apple would make later.

You were six when Windows 95 came out. You were ten when Google launched. Thirteen when the first iPod arrived. Fifteen when Facebook opened to high schools. Sixteen when the iPhone dropped. You didn't grow up with smartphones—you watched them take over in real-time.

This makes you the last generation to remember life before the internet was everywhere. You know what it's like to be bored without a screen to fill the void. You remember printing out MapQuest directions. You can operate both a rotary phone and a touchscreen.

Your relationship with technology is complicated. You're digital natives who remember analog life. You can troubleshoot your parents' Wi-Fi and your grandparents' VCR. You're fluent in social media but old enough to remember when it didn't exist. That perspective makes you weird in ways younger people don't quite understand.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were three months old when Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. You don't remember it, but it was the prelude to everything that came later—the security state, the fear, the way airports became places you submit to authority without question.

You were one when the Berlin Wall fell. Three when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War was your parents' defining anxiety, not yours. Your anxiety came later, in different forms.

You were six when Princess Diana died. Everyone watched her funeral. You probably didn't understand why the adults were so upset about a princess in a faraway country, but you learned that collective grief was a thing people did together, usually on television.

You were ten when Columbine happened. That was the first school shooting that felt like a school shooting—the template for everything after. You probably had your first lockdown drill not long after. School went from a safe place to a place where you practiced hiding.

You were thirteen during 9/11. You watched the second plane hit live. You saw people jump. The adults in your life tried to explain what was happening, but nobody really knew. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started soon after and just kept going. Your entire adolescence happened against the background noise of forever war.

You were twenty during the 2008 financial crisis. You graduated—or were about to graduate—into the worst economy since the Great Depression. Job prospects evaporated. Housing became a fantasy. The message was clear: the future your parents promised wasn't available at any price.

By the time you were twenty-five, same-sex marriage was legal nationwide. By thirty, Donald Trump was president. By thirty-two, there was a global pandemic. History didn't stop. It accelerated. You've lived through more destabilizing events than any generation since the Greatest Generation, and you did it all while being told you were too sensitive, too entitled, too soft.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated into the 2008 financial crisis or its immediate aftermath. The job market was a nightmare. Entry-level positions required five years of experience. Internships were unpaid. The gig economy wasn't liberation—it was exploitation with better branding.

Your generation pioneered the concept of 'side hustles' because one job didn't pay enough. You learned to list 'passion' and 'purpose' on resumes because employers wanted you to care deeply about their mission while paying you barely enough to survive.

You're the generation that normalized job-hopping. Not because you're disloyal, but because companies stopped being loyal first. Pensions vanished. Raises became 'you're lucky to have a job' speeches. The social contract between employers and employees was shredded before you even entered the workforce.

You've worked in offices with ping pong tables and 'unlimited vacation' policies that nobody uses because the culture punishes taking time off. You've sat through diversity training while watching the C-suite remain aggressively homogenous. You've been told to 'lean in' while the ladder you're leaning on gets pulled away.

Remote work became normalized because of COVID, which was probably the only good thing to come out of that mess. You proved you could do your job from anywhere, which means employers now expect you to do your job from everywhere, all the time, on your phone.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that invented modern dating app culture, which is less an invention and more a slow-motion car crash you all witnessed from inside the vehicle. Tinder launched when you were in your mid-twenties. You watched courtship become a swipe-based sorting algorithm.

You probably met at least one partner online, which your grandparents find baffling and your Gen Z cousins find completely normal. You're the bridge generation—old enough to remember meeting people in person, young enough to have normalized meeting them on screens.

You communicate primarily through text, but you remember calling people on actual phones. You know the anxiety of waiting for someone to respond, and you know the different anxieties that come with read receipts. You've had entire relationships happen via DM.

Your generation delayed marriage longer than any previous generation. Not because you don't want partnerships, but because weddings are expensive, houses are expensive, kids are expensive, and your student loans are crushing. The life script your parents followed isn't available at a price you can afford.

You've normalized long-distance relationships because you've all moved for work, for school, for cheaper rent. You've maintained friendships across time zones via group chats. You know how to be close to people who are far away and distant from people who are near.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were thirteen when the dot-com bubble burst. Twenty during the 2008 financial crisis. Thirty-two during the COVID-19 economic collapse. You've watched the economy implode three times before hitting middle age. This has given you a financial worldview best described as 'permanently braced for impact.'

Your relationship with money is defined by scarcity that never seems to end. You graduated with student loan debt that will follow you for decades. You watched housing prices climb while your wages stagnated. The American Dream—house, car, kids, retirement—became a punchline.

You save obsessively because you've seen how fast stability evaporates. You invest reluctantly because you don't trust the stock market, but you don't trust Social Security either, so what's the alternative? You're playing a rigged game because not playing means losing by default.

You've been lectured about avocado toast and lattes by people who bought houses for $80,000 in 1994. The generational wealth gap is staggering, and you're on the wrong side of it. Boomers accumulated assets when they were cheap. You're accumulating debt while assets are expensive.

Your generation is redefining what financial success looks like. It's not homeownership—it's paying rent in a city you can't afford because the jobs are there. It's not retirement at 65—it's working until something breaks. It's not leaving money to your kids—it's hoping you won't be a financial burden to them.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is the same as its biggest strength: you believe you can optimize everything. You track your sleep, your steps, your macros, your screen time. You approach self-improvement like it's a productivity hack. The problem is you can't gamify your way out of systemic problems.

You're so good at adapting to broken systems that you sometimes forget to question whether the systems should exist at all. You've normalized precarity. You've accepted that healthcare is tied to employment, that education requires debt, that retirement is a fantasy. You've learned to cope instead of demanding change.

You're conflict-averse in ways that don't serve you. You've been trained to be team players, to not rock the boat, to bring solutions not problems. This makes you easy to exploit. You'll work unpaid overtime for 'exposure.' You'll accept 'equity' instead of salary. You'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance.

You're so steeped in irony and self-deprecation that earnestness feels dangerous. You can't just like something—you have to like it ironically, or like it despite its flaws, or explain why liking it is actually a critique. This makes it hard to advocate for yourself without hedging, apologizing, or making it a joke.

Your generation is so online that you sometimes forget offline life is where the actual stakes are. You can mobilize for causes on social media, but voter turnout lags. You can cancel celebrities, but changing policy requires showing up to boring city council meetings. The digital activism feels like action, but it's often just performance.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2008-2018): You graduated into an economic crater. You took jobs you were overqualified for. You moved back home or lived with five roommates. You delayed everything—marriage, kids, homeownership—because the economics didn't work. This was supposed to be your 'finding yourself' decade. Instead, it was your 'surviving the Great Recession' decade.

Your 30s (2018-2028): You're in this decade now. You're probably making more money than you did at 25, but it still doesn't feel like enough. You're watching younger people enter the workforce and older people retire, and you're stuck in the middle, too established to start over, too financially insecure to relax. This is the decade where you're supposed to 'settle down,' but settling feels like giving up. You're trying to build stability on a foundation that keeps shifting.

Your 40s (2028-2038): This will be your peak earning decade, statistically. You'll probably have more authority at work, more clarity about what you want, more acceptance of what you can't change. Your kids, if you have them, will be older. Your parents will be aging, which brings new responsibilities. You'll be sandwiched between generations, managing everyone else's needs while your own needs get pushed to the back burner. This is the decade where you either double down on the life you've built or blow it up and start over.

Your 50s (2038-2048): By now, you'll have lived through at least four economic crises, two pandemics (statistically likely), and countless 'once in a generation' events that seem to happen every other year. You'll be pre-retirement age but unable to retire because retirement isn't financially viable. You'll be mentoring younger people who don't understand why you're so scarred by 2008. You'll be annoyed at how they don't appreciate the ways things are better now, and annoyed at yourself for sounding like every older generation that came before.

Your 60s and beyond (2048+): Retirement, if you can afford it, won't look like your parents' retirement. It'll be part-time work, gig economy hustle, or reliance on kids who are struggling themselves. Social Security might still exist. It might not. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable from the one you grew up in. You'll tell younger people what life was like before smartphones, before the internet, before everything moved online. They won't believe you.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.9 million people born in 1988. The entire Millennial generation is about 72 million people in the US, making it the largest generation until Gen Z overtakes it sometime in the next decade.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer. Gen X inherited a functioning economy and broke it before passing it to you. They got affordable college. You got student loans. They got pensions. You got 401(k)s. They got stability. You got the gig economy.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is staggering. Boomers controlled 21% of the nation's wealth when they were your age. Millennials control 7%. Boomers bought houses for a year's salary. You're spending a year's salary on rent. Boomers retired with pensions. You're hoping Social Security still exists when you're 70.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're similar but slightly more optimistic. You remember a time before everything was terrible. Gen Z doesn't. You believed the system could be fixed. Gen Z knows it's broken and is building alternatives. You adapted to smartphones. They were born with them. You're the last generation to remember the before times.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, which is slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, drugs, alcohol. Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before. You're more anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world you inherited is harder, lonelier, and more expensive than the one promised to you.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before. You've normalized therapy, destigmatized mental health, and pushed for equity in ways your parents' generation didn't. You've made the world more inclusive even as it's become less affordable. That's not nothing.

year_events: George H.W. Bush won the presidency
Die Hard invented the modern action movie
